docs.title: GitHub AI Projects Package
docs.text: Welcome to the GitHub AI Projects Package documentation. This repository implements an Elite Continuous Delivery Pipeline with advanced CI/CD capabilities.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This repository contains a collection of AI projects packaged with professional-grade DevOps infrastructure:

  • Multi-platform Docker builds (amd64/arm64)
  • Advanced caching strategies for fast builds
  • Supply chain security with Cosign signing and SLSA provenance
  • Automated semantic versioning
  • Professional documentation with versioning support

docs.title: Elite CI/CD Pipeline
docs.text:
• ✅ GitHub Actions orchestration
  • ✅ BuildKit with docker-container driver

  • ✅ Multi-platform builds using QEMU
  • ✅ Keyless signing with Sigstore Cosign
  • ✅ SBOM and provenance attestations
  • ✅ Semantic Release automation

docs.title: Developer Experience
docs.text:

  • ✅ Branch protection with PR reviews

docs.title: CI/CD Pipeline Architecture
docs.text: This document provides an in-depth analysis of the Elite Continuous Delivery Pipeline.

docs.title: Pipeline Overview
docs.text: The pipeline implements a three-job workflow that executes on every push, pull request, and manual trigger.

docs.title: Trigger Configuration
docs.text:
on:
  push:
    branches: ["**"]        # All branches
    tags-ignore: ["v*"]     # Avoid double-trigger
  pull_request:
    branches: ["master", "main"]
  workflow_dispatch:        # Manual trigger

docs.title: Concurrency Control
docs.text:
Prevents resource waste by canceling outdated runs:

concurrency:
  group: ${{ github.workflow }}-${{ github.ref }}
  cancel-in-progress: true

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: Fast feedback loop for code quality issues.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Free Disk Space: Removes unnecessary files (~14GB)
  2. Checkout: Clones the repository
  3. Install Task: Sets up the task runner
  4. Lint & Test: Runs quality checks

docs.title: Performance
docs.text: Typically completes in 2-3 minutes.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: Builds, signs, and publishes container images with semantic versioning.

docs.title: 1. Semantic Release
docs.text:
Runs only on main/master branches:

  • Analyzes commit history
  • Determines next version
  • Generates changelog
  • Creates GitHub release
  • Tags the repository

docs.title: 2. Multi-Platform Setup
docs.text:
QEMU: Enables ARM64 emulation on AMD64 runners

BuildKit: Latest version with docker-container driver

- uses: docker/setup-qemu-action@v3
- uses: docker/setup-buildx-action@v3
  with:
    driver-opts: image=moby/buildkit:latest

docs.title: 3. Registry Authentication
docs.text:
Logs into GitHub Container Registry (GHCR):

- uses: docker/login-action@v3
  with:
    registry: ghcr.io
    username: ${{ github.actor }}
    password: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}

docs.title: 4. Metadata Extraction
docs.text:
Generates tags based on context:

  • Release: v1.2.3, latest
  • Branch: branch-name
  • PR: pr-123
  • Commit: sha-abc123

docs.title: 5. Build and Push
docs.text:
The core build step with advanced features:

- uses: docker/build-push-action@v6
  with:
    platforms: linux/amd64,linux/arm64
    cache-from: type=gha
    cache-to: type=gha,mode=max,compression=zstd
    provenance: mode=max
    sbom: true

Key Features:

  • Multi-platform: Builds for AMD64 and ARM64
  • Advanced Caching: GHA backend with mode=max
  • Compression: Zstandard for faster I/O
  • Provenance: SLSA attestations
  • SBOM: Software Bill of Materials

docs.title: 6. Image Signing
docs.text:
Keyless signing with Sigstore Cosign:

cosign sign --yes ${images}

Benefits: - No key management - OIDC-based identity - Transparency log (Rekor) - Cryptographic verification

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
• First run: 10-15 minutes (no cache)
  • Subsequent runs: 3-5 minutes (with cache)
  • Cache hit rate: 80-90% for dependencies

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: Deploys versioned documentation to GitHub Pages.

docs.title: Conditional Execution
docs.text:
Runs only when a new release is published:

if: needs.pipeline.outputs.release_published == 'true'

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Checkout: Full history for versioning
  2. Setup Python: Installs Python 3.x
  3. Install Tools: MkDocs Material and mike
  4. Configure Git: Sets up committer identity
  5. Deploy: Publishes versioned docs

docs.title: Versioning with mike
docs.text:
mike deploy --push --update-aliases $VERSION latest

Creates a version dropdown in the documentation UI.

docs.title: GHA Backend
docs.text:
Uses GitHub Actions cache API:

Advantages: - Fast restore (internal network) - Automatic eviction (10GB limit) - Scoped to repository

docs.title: mode=max
docs.text:
Caches all intermediate layers:

Impact: - Caches expensive dependency installation - Reduces build time by 70-80% - Increases cache size

docs.title: Zstandard Compression
docs.text:
Faster decompression than gzip:

Impact: - Reduces I/O bottleneck - Faster cache loading - Similar compression ratio

docs.title: SLSA Provenance
docs.text:
Generates build attestations:

  • Build parameters
  • Git SHA
  • Builder identity
  • Timestamp

docs.title: SBOM
docs.text:
Software Bill of Materials:

  • All dependencies
  • Version information
  • Vulnerability scanning

docs.title: Cosign Signing
docs.text:
Keyless signing workflow:

  1. Workflow requests OIDC token
  2. Fulcio issues certificate
  3. Image is signed
  4. Signature logged in Rekor

docs.title: Verification
docs.text:
Consumers can verify images:

cosign verify \
  --certificate-identity-regexp=https://github.com/lordwilsonDev/GITHUB_AI_PROJECTS_PACKAGE \
  ghcr.io/lordwilsondev/github_ai_projects_package:latest

docs.title: Branch Protection
docs.text:
Enforces quality gates:

  • Require PR reviews: Prevents direct pushes
  • Require status checks: Blocks broken code
  • Linear history: Enables semantic versioning

docs.title: Feature Branches
docs.text:
Every push creates a tagged image:

  • branch-name
  • sha-abc123

docs.title: Main/Master Branch
docs.text:
Semantic versioning:

  • v1.2.3 (semantic version)
  • latest (latest release)

docs.title: Pull Requests
docs.text:
PR-specific tags:

  • pr-123

docs.title: Workflow Annotations
docs.text: Errors and warnings appear in the GitHub UI.

docs.title: Build Logs
docs.text:
Detailed logs for debugging:

  • Disk space usage
  • Cache hit/miss
  • Build duration
  • Layer sizes

docs.title: Release Notes
docs.text: Automatically generated from commits.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Use Conventional Commits: Enables automated versioning
  2. Keep builds fast: Optimize Dockerfile layers
  3. Monitor cache hit rate: Adjust caching strategy
  4. Review security attestations: Verify provenance
  5. Update dependencies: Use Renovate or Dependabot

docs.title: Disk Space Issues
docs.text:
The pipeline includes aggressive cleanup:

sudo rm -rf /usr/share/dotnet
sudo rm -rf /usr/local/lib/android
sudo docker image prune --all --force

docs.title: Cache Misses
docs.text:
Check if dependencies changed:

  • requirements.txt modifications
  • Base image updates
  • Dockerfile changes

docs.title: Build Failures
docs.text:
Review logs for:

  • Syntax errors
  • Missing dependencies
  • Network issues
  • Platform-specific problems

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text: This document provides a comprehensive overview of the GitHub AI Projects Package architecture.

docs.title: Repository Structure
docs.text: The repository follows a professional structure that separates concerns:

docs.title: Root Level
docs.text:
• Taskfile.yml: Unified task runner configuration
  • Dockerfile: Multi-stage optimized container build
  • .dockerignore: Build context optimization
  • mkdocs.yml: Documentation configuration
  • .releaserc.json: Semantic Release configuration

docs.title: .github Directory
docs.text:
Contains all GitHub-specific configurations:

  • workflows/ci.yml: Elite CI/CD pipeline
  • ISSUE_TEMPLATE/: Issue templates for bug reports and feature requests
  • PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE/: PR template for consistent contributions

docs.title: docs Directory
docs.text: Contains all documentation in Markdown format, organized by topic.

docs.title: 1. Taskfile (Task Runner)
docs.text:
Replaces traditional Makefiles with a modern YAML-based task runner:

Advantages: - YAML syntax (consistent with GitHub Actions) - Cross-platform compatibility - Built-in parallelism - Checksum-based caching - Local/CI parity

docs.title: 2. Multi-Stage Dockerfile
docs.text:
Optimized for BuildKit with two stages:

Builder Stage: - Installs system dependencies - Collects and installs Python requirements - Prepares application dependencies

Runtime Stage: - Minimal Python slim image - Copies only necessary artifacts - Optimized for size and security

docs.title: 3. GitHub Actions Workflow
docs.text:
Three-phase pipeline:

Phase 1: Quality Assurance - Disk space cleanup - Linting and testing - Fast feedback loop

Phase 2: Build & Release - Semantic versioning - Multi-platform Docker builds - Supply chain security (Cosign, SBOM, provenance) - Image signing

Phase 3: Documentation - Conditional on release - Versioned documentation deployment - GitHub Pages integration

docs.title: 1. Shift-Left Security
docs.text: Security is integrated from the start: - Keyless signing with Sigstore Cosign - SLSA provenance generation - SBOM (Software Bill of Materials) - Cryptographic verification

docs.title: 2. Developer Experience (DevEx)
docs.text: Optimized for developer productivity: - Single command execution (task ci) - Local/CI parity - Fast feedback loops - Clear error messages

docs.title: 3. Performance
docs.text: Optimized for speed: - Advanced caching (GHA backend, mode=max, zstd) - Parallel execution - Incremental builds - Efficient layer caching

docs.title: 4. Maintainability
docs.text: Designed for long-term maintenance: - Clear separation of concerns - Self-documenting configuration - Automated dependency updates (Renovate-ready) - Comprehensive documentation

docs.title: Technology Stack
docs.text:
• CI/CD: GitHub Actions
  • Container Runtime: Docker with BuildKit
  • Task Runner: Task (Taskfile)
  • Documentation: MkDocs Material with mike
  • Versioning: Semantic Release
  • Security: Sigstore Cosign
  • Registry: GitHub Container Registry (GHCR)

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This guide will help you set up the development environment for the GitHub AI Projects Package.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Git: Version control system
  • Docker: Container runtime (20.10+)
  • Task: Modern task runner (installation guide)
  • Python: 3.11 or higher (for local development)

docs.title: Installing Task
docs.text: Task is our unified task runner that provides parity between local and CI environments.

docs.title: macOS
docs.text: brew install go-task

docs.title: Linux
docs.text: sh -c "$(curl --location https://taskfile.dev/install.sh)" -- -d -b ~/.local/bin

docs.title: Windows
docs.text: choco install go-task

docs.title: Cloning the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/lordwilsonDev/GITHUB_AI_PROJECTS_PACKAGE.git
cd GITHUB_AI_PROJECTS_PACKAGE

docs.title: Verifying Installation
docs.text:
Run the following command to verify your setup:

task --version

You should see the Task version number.

docs.title: Docker Setup
docs.text:
Ensure Docker is running:

docker --version
docker ps

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Once you have everything installed, proceed to the Quick Start guide to learn how to use the repository.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: This guide will help you quickly get started with the GitHub AI Projects Package.

docs.title: Available Tasks
docs.text:
The repository uses Taskfile for unified command execution. View all available tasks:

task --list

docs.title: Running Tests and Linting
docs.text:
Run the default quality checks (lint + test):

task default

Or run them individually:

task lint
task test

docs.title: Local Build
docs.text:
Build the Docker image locally:

task build

docs.title: Advanced Build
docs.text:
Build with multi-platform support (requires Docker Buildx):

task build:advanced

docs.title: Local Preview
docs.text:
Serve the documentation locally with live reload:

task docs:serve

Then open http://localhost:8000 in your browser.

docs.title: Building Documentation
docs.text:
Build the static documentation site:

task docs:build

docs.title: CI/CD Workflow
docs.text:
The repository uses an Elite Continuous Delivery Pipeline that automatically:

  1. On every push: Runs quality checks and builds Docker images
  2. On main/master: Performs semantic versioning and creates releases
  3. On release: Publishes versioned documentation

docs.title: Making Changes
docs.text:
1. Create a feature branch: 

    git checkout -b feat/my-feature

  2. Make your changes and commit using Conventional Commits: 

    git commit -m "feat: add new feature"

  3. Push and create a Pull Request: 

    git push origin feat/my-feature

docs.title: Conventional Commits
docs.text:
This repository uses Conventional Commits for automated versioning:

  • feat: - New feature (minor version bump)
  • fix: - Bug fix (patch version bump)
  • docs: - Documentation changes (no version bump)
  • chore: - Maintenance tasks (no version bump)
  • BREAKING CHANGE: - Breaking change (major version bump)
